definition: to run like the wind/to rush/to gallop
to fly
(of an animal) to paw (the ground)
to run/to run away/to escape/to run around (on errands etc)/(of a gas or liquid) to leak or evaporate/(verb complement) away/off

sentences.english: Why, I always go down at full gallop.
sentences.chinese: 噢，我總是打着馬飛跑下山的。

sentences.english: The horses were raring to have a gallop.
sentences.chinese: 這些馬都急不可耐地要飛跑起來。

sentences.english: Their feet are swift to shed blood
sentences.chinese: 殺人流血他們的腳飛跑。

sentences.english: He grabbed the wheelchair and pushed her along.
sentences.chinese: 他一把抓過輪椅，推着她飛跑起來。

sentences.english: The children flew to meet their mother.
sentences.chinese: 孩子們飛跑過去迎接媽媽。

sentences.english: He opened one eye in time to see a tiny gray shadow whisk past.
sentences.chinese: 他睜開一隻眼睛，看到一個小小的灰色影子飛跑過去。

sentences.english: He hared off down the road.
A car rolls into the village and children dash to meet it.
sentences.chinese: 一輛汽車駛進村莊，兒童們飛跑過去迎接。

sentences.english: Down the broad white road ran jack .
sentences.chinese: 傑克沿着白色寬闊大道飛跑。

sentences.english: The children ran to the barn.
sentences.chinese: 孩子們飛跑到穀倉去了。

sentences.english: White Flower flew out of doors and warned him.
sentences.chinese: 白花飛跑出門，向他發出了警報。

sentences.english: The little girl flew to her grandmother.
sentences.chinese: 這女孩向她奶奶飛跑過去。

definition: filthy speech/obscenities
arrogant and despotic
see 心驚膽戰|心惊胆战[xin1 jing1 dan3 zhan4]
to die (idiom)/to breathe one's last/to give up the ghost
sullen/to scowl miserably
indirect, psychological method of getting sb to do as one wishes (e.g. questioning whether they are up to the task)
fig. restless, because of fear or strong emotions
to feel guilty as a thief (idiom); to have sth on one's conscience
lit. if you agree to bet you must accept to lose/fig. you bet, you pay
red in the face/extremely angry
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
grinning from ear to ear (idiom)/beaming with happiness
phonograph or radio (old term)/chatterbox/talkative person
to make love
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
to fly into a rage out of humiliation/to be ashamed into anger (idiom)
